channel.title: Yet another math problem
channel.description:
If (1/x) + (1/y) = (1/4) and (1/x) - (1/y) = (3/4), then x = ?
i need to show work all help is appreciated :)

item.title: Yet another math problem
item.dc:creator: @ran_fan06 ran_fan06
item.description:
@ran_fan06 wrote:

hi, I’m new here
erm, these are things u need to know : i. (2/y) = (-2/4)
so, y=-4

                                                 ii. (2/x) = (4/4)
                                                    so, x=2

the 1st one, u juz minus the 1st equation with the 2nd
that is (1/x) + (1/y) = (1/4)
-(1/x) - (1/y) = (3/4) {(1/x) - (1/x) = 0 }
{(1/y) - (-1/y) = (2/y) }
{(1/4) - (3/4) = (-2/4)}

the 2nd one, juz plus both of the equation
that is (1/x) + (1/y) = (1/4)
+(1/x) - (1/y) = (3/4) {(1/x) + (1/x) = (2/x)}
{(1/y) + (-1/y) = 0 }
{(1/4) + (3/4) = (4/4)}

then, put the calculation in the equation back
now, the equation 4 x will be
(2/x) + 0 = (4/4), means (2/x) = (4/4)

4 need to divide by 2 to get 2
therefore, x = 2, as the upper is 2

lol, juz postin these… hehe

Read full topic

item.title: Yet another math problem
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Workings out are too much of a pain to show for this online imo… But try solving it simultaneously; you will end up with 2/x = 1, so obviously x = 2. Then you can solve further. 2/y = -1/2, and so y = -4.

Read full topic
